ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: My Spanish improved, including my speaking and writing abilities.
Worked on grammar, speaking, and writing in Spanish.
I learnt a lot about Hispanic culture through the use of film, news articles, books, and general media. I really got a good exposure to different festivals and literature.
I feel much more comfortable speaking, understanding, and reading Spanish. I also feel like I learned a lot about the culture and history (and how they are related) of Latin and South America.
I practiced my Spanish, particularly my ability to listen and comprehension to information communicated verbally to me.
Added contribution to in-class conversation, greater mastery of various verb tenses that I can now use to speak with.
Culture

The course offered a vibrant learning environment that encouraged active application of skills within a supportive community. Under the guidance of an exceptional professor, the classroom thrived with an emphasis on honing our speaking abilities and exploring Spanish through diverse multimedia resources. By centering the curriculum around social issues, the class provided an exceptional platform for students to engage deeply with distinctive content and materials.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I appreciated the variety of approaches (movies, readings of essays, learning about art exhibitions, understanding different cultures in Latin America) and the discussions in class. I would have liked more formal teaching of the grammar, especially to introduce big concepts (like the subjunctive).
Working in small groups was a strength as well as work on asynchronous class days. Sometimes it was difficult to work with people outside of class if we hadn't already had time in class.

The structure of the course was really amazing. I enjoyed every class and the topics as mentioned before were engaging and appealing. The asynchronous class on Wednesday provided an opportunity to consolidate learning at your own pace. As a comment, I felt that these were better when we were working in groups - if the asynchronous structure wasn't kept, then perhaps an opportunity to come to class and work in groups would be good (this aspect of the class should definitely be kept).
Strengths: Professor Sanchez!

Jamboards are much better alternative to worksheets and are less overwhelming/stressful. Sometimes out of class responsibilites/homework could be more clear. 

I appreciated the independent nature of class conversation and how it taught me to insert myself into the conversation much more often.
I wish we did more relevant things

The class had several notable strengths that contributed to its effectiveness. One of these strengths was its high level of organization and structure, which provided students with clear expectations regarding classroom work, assignments, and overall course requirements. This allowed us to approach each week with a solid understanding of what to expect. Moreover, the instructor's unique and admirable teaching philosophy added great value to the course. Her approach ignited excitement and appreciation among students, making the learning experience both engaging and meaningful.

However, a weakness arose from the hierarchical structure of the Spanish department, which sometimes hindered the instructor's ability to implement certain teaching methods or approaches she deemed valuable. While she may have wanted to deviate from the established norms, the department's cohesive framework limited her options. This restriction might have posed challenges in fully realizing her vision for the course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend. A good mix of writing and speaking. Uses various types of media in teaching as well.
Absolutely, especially if Noelia is teaching. Having a background in 2nd language acquisition meant she really knows how to approach language teaching in an efficient and interesting way.
Yes! If Professor Sanchez Walker is teaching, you'll learn so much and it will be such a fun time.
Certainly--excellent course that forces students to improve their Spanish by attending/participating in class every day.
yes, if you want to get credit for a language

Absolutely! The Spanish learning experience at Yale demands dedication, but professors like Noelia truly make it a rewarding journey. Throughout the semester, I had the privilege of dedicating a significant portion of my time to enhancing my Spanish skills and developing strategies to further expand my knowledge. The course deviated from a narrow focus on vocabulary and grammar, instead offering ample opportunities for cultural exploration and enrichment by delving into the diverse cultures and people of Spanish-speaking countries. This shift allowed for a more holistic and immersive learning experience that went beyond language mechanics.
